workflow.name: AI-powered email support router with Gmail, ChatGPT-4o, and Slack
workflow.description:
### This n8n template automates your customer support workflow by connecting Gmail, OpenAI, Supabase, and Slack. It listens for new incoming emails, classifies them using AI, routes them to the appropriate Slack channel based on category (e.g., support or new requests), logs each thread to Supabase for tracking, and marks the email as read once processed.

###### Good to know
	‚Ä¢	The OpenAI API is used for automatic email classification, which incurs a small per-request cost. See OpenAI Pricing for up-to-date info.
	‚Ä¢	You can easily expand the categories or connect more Slack channels to fit your workflow.
	‚Ä¢	The Supabase integration ensures you don‚Äôt process the same thread twice.

### How it works
	1.	Gmail Trigger checks for unread emails.
	2.	Supabase Get Row verifies if the thread already exists.
	3.	If it‚Äôs a new thread, the OpenAI node classifies the email into categories such as ‚Äúsupport‚Äù or ‚Äúnew-request.‚Äù
	4.	The Switch node routes messages to the correct Slack channel based on classification.
	5.	Supabase Create Row logs thread details (sender, subject, IDs) to your database.
	6.	Finally, the Gmail node marks the message as read to prevent duplication.

### How to use
	‚Ä¢	The workflow uses a manual Gmail trigger by default, but you can adjust the polling frequency.
	‚Ä¢	Modify category names or Slack channels to match your internal setup.
	‚Ä¢	Extend the workflow to include auto-replies or ticket creation in your CRM.

### Requirements
	‚Ä¢	Gmail account (with OAuth2 credentials)
	‚Ä¢	Slack workspace (with channel access)
	‚Ä¢	OpenAI account for classification
	‚Ä¢	Supabase project for storing thread data

### Customizing this workflow
Use this automation to triage incoming requests, route sales leads to specific teams, or even filter internal communications. You can add nodes for auto-responses, CRM logging, or task creation in Notion or ClickUp.

values.content:
=You are an email triage classifier. Return ONLY a JSON object:
{"category":"support|new-request|enquiry|general|spam|other"}

parameters.content:
## 1. Gmail Trigger
üì¨ Triggers whenever a new unread email arrives in the connected Gmail inbox.

‚û°Ô∏è Sends email data (From, Subject, Snippet, Thread ID, etc.) to the next node.

## 2. Get a row (Supabase) 
üîç Checks Supabase table ‚Äúthreads‚Äù to see if this email thread already exists.

## 3. IF Node
‚ùìDecision point:
	‚Ä¢	If thread exists, stop (no duplicate processing).
	‚Ä¢	If thread does not exist, continue workflow.

## 4. Message a Model (OpenAI)
üß† Sends the email subject and snippet to ChatGPT (4o) to classify the email into a category:
support | new-request | enquiry | general | spam | other

## 5. Switch
üîÄ Routes the email based on the category returned by ChatGPT:
	‚Ä¢	If ‚Äúsupport‚Äù ‚Üí send to #support channel.
	‚Ä¢	If ‚Äúnew-request‚Äù ‚Üí send to #new-requests channel.

parameters.text: =New request received from  {{ $('Gmail Trigger').item.json.From }} Subject: {{ $('Gmail Trigger').item.json.Subject }} Content: {{ $('Gmail Trigger').item.json.snippet }}

parameters.content:
## 6. Send a Message (Slack)
üí¨ Posts formatted message in the #support Slack channel:

‚ÄúNew support request received from [email]. Subject: [‚Ä¶]. Content: [‚Ä¶]‚Äù

## 7. Send a Message 2 (Slack)
üí¨ Posts formatted message in the #new-requests Slack channel:

‚ÄúNew request received from [email]. Subject: [‚Ä¶]. Content: [‚Ä¶]‚Äù

## 8. Create a Row (Supabase)
üóÉÔ∏è Adds a new record in the ‚Äúthreads‚Äù table:
Stores thread_id, first_message_id, from_addr, subject for future deduplication.

## 9. Mark a Message as Read (Gmail)
‚úÖ Marks the email as read in Gmail once it‚Äôs processed and saved.

user.name: Bohdan Saranchuk
user.bio: Automation consultant and founder of Bosar Agency. I help businesses integrate AI and automation into their workflows using tools like n8n, OpenAI, and custom-built solutions.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
